result.execSummary:
The defendant Terrell D Cobbs was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Retail Theft - Intentionally Take (<=$500) [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.50(1m)(b).
  • Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Statutory costs assessed.   If supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.

No alcohol or controlled substances except by prescription. Random UA's are authorized. Any counseling deemed appropriate by agent; specifically cognitive intervention and mental health assessment and follow through. Must obtain and maintain full time verifiable employment. No contact, directly or indirectly, with victims and co-actors. Defendant may not enter into KMart, ShopKo, or Wal Mart.    Defendant must obey all rules and regulations while on probation.

No alcohol or controlled substances except by prescription. Random UA's are authorized. Any counseling deemed appropriate by agent; specifically cognitive intervention and mental health assessment and follow through. Must obtain and maintain full time verifiable employment. No contact, directly or indirectly, with victims and co-actors. Defendant may not enter into KMart, ShopKo, or Wal Mart.   Defendant must submit a DNA sample as required by law and pay for the testing. Firearm warning given. Voting is prohibited until sentence is complete and civil rights have been restored. Defendant must obey all rules and regulations while on probation.

AMENDED 06-15-2015; DEFENDANT IS ALLOWED 5 HOURS PER WEEK FOR GROCERY SHOPPING AND LAUNDRY AS WELL AS MEDICAL APPOINTMENTS. DEFENDANT MAY ATTEND FUNERAL AT ST. PAUL BAPTIST CHURCH ON JUNE 16, 2015 FROM 10:30 AM TO 3:00 PM. IF THE FUNERAL IS OVER SOONER THAN 3:00 PM, DEFENDANT MUST RETURN HOME. DEFENDANT MAY SERVE ON JURY DUTY.

Defense asks that the case be recalled for defense to request bond be modified to allow him to take care of personal matters such as grocery shopping. Defense suggests 5 hours per week. Deft is asking to attend a funeral tomorrow as well. The State does not object to 1 or 2 hours per week for grocery shopping and to attend the funeral.

BTC: Modify bond to allow deft 5 hours a week for shopping, laundry and medical appointments. Deft may attend funeral at St. Paul Baptist church from 10:30 am to 3 pm tomorrow, June 16. If funeral is finished early, deft must return home. Deft may attend jury duty.
Sentencing hearing on July 28, 2015 at 10:00 am.
